revisions.rev:
{{NCAATeamSeason |Mode = baseball |Year = 2009 |Team = Clemson Tigers |Conference = Atlantic Coast Conference |Division =Atlantic |ShortConference = ACC |Record = 44-22 |ConfRecord = 19-11 |HeadCoach = [[Jack Leggett]] |StadiumArena = [[Doug Kingsmore Stadium]] |Champion = Clemson, SC Regional Champions |BowlTourney = Tempe, AZ Super Regional |BowlTourneyResult = (L 4-7, L 2-8) }} The '''2009 Clemson Tigers baseball team''' represented [[Clemson University]] in the [[2009]] [[NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] [[college baseball|baseball]] [[2009 NCAA Division I baseball season|season]]. The team played their home games at [[Doug Kingsmore Stadium]] in [[Clemson, SC]]. The team was coached by [[Jack Leggett]] in his sixteenth season at Clemson. ==Preseason== On January 27, 2009, the coaches in the ACC picked Clemson to finish second in the Atlantic Division behind Florida State. Overall, the Tigers were picked third behind North Carolina and Florida State respectively.{{cite web | url=http://www.theacc.com/sports/m-basebl/spec-rel/012709aaa.html | work=Baseball | publisher=The ACC | title=North Carolina leads ACC Baseball Coaches Preseason Poll | accessdate=2009-01-27 }} ==Regular season== On March 5, 2009, Head Coach Jack Leggett announced that Fifth-year shortstop Stan Widmann had left the team due to personal reasons. Widmann, who graduated from Clemson with a degree in sport management the previous December, had withdrawn from school to pursue job opportunities.{{cite web | url=http://www.thestate.com/tigers/v-print/story/704095.html | work=The State | publisher=the McClatchy Company | title=Injuries force Tigersâ Widmann to end career | accessdate=2009-03-05 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} On Wednesday, March 18, pitchers Justin Sarratt, Scott Weismann, Kyle Deese, Tomas Cruz, and Matt Vaughn combined to pitch a [[no-hitter]] in Clemson's 14-0 victory over [[USC Upstate]] at [[Doug Kingsmore Stadium]]. It was the Tigers' 14th no-hitter in school history and first since the second game of a doubleheader on March 6, 1984, when Scott Parrish no-hit [[The Citadel (military college)|The Citadel]] in a seven-inning game. It was also just the second no-hitter involving multiple pitchers in Tiger history.{{cite web | url=http://clemsontigers.cstv.com/sports/m-basebl/recaps/031809aab.html | work=ClemsonTigers.com | publisher=Clemson University Athletic Department | title=#18 Clemson No-Hits USC Upstate in 14-0 Win Wednesday | accessdate=2009-03-18 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5hgJQUxMZ|archivedate=2009-06-20|deadurl=no}} On Tuesday, April 21, sophomore outfielder Jeff Shaus hit a [[Walk-off home run|walk-off]] [[Grand slam (baseball)|grand slam]] to lift the Tigers to a 5-3 victory over the visiting [[Coastal Carolina Chanticleers]]. It was Clemson's first walk-off home run since April 27, 2007, when Doug Hogan hit a walkoff solo homer to top [[Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets baseball|Georgia Tech]] 3-2 in 11 innings. It was also the second walkoff grand slam in Tiger history, matching the walkoff grand slam hit by Tyler Colvin in the Tigers' 11-8 win over [[Oral Roberts Golden Eagles|Oral Roberts]] in the [[2006 NCAA Division I Baseball Tournament|2006 Clemson Super Regional]].{{cite web | url=http://clemsontigers.cstv.com/sports/m-basebl/recaps/042109aab.html | work=ClemsonTigers.com | publisher=Clemson University Athletic Department | title=Schaus' Walkoff Grand Slam Lifts No. 20 Tigers Over No. 19 Chanticleers 5-3 Tuesday | accessdate=2009-04-21 }} ==Postseason== ===ACC Tournament=== Clemson went 1-2 in the [[2009 ACC Baseball Tournament]] with losses to 7-seeded Duke and eventual champs, 6-seeded Virginia. On May 23, in their final game of the tournament, Clemson beat 2-seeded and top-five nationally ranked North Carolina in eleven innings in front of a crowd of 6,956. This set a record for the highest attendance ever at a college baseball game in the state of North Carolina. ===NCAA Tournament=== Clemson was awarded a host site for the regional round of the [[2009 NCAA Division I Baseball Tournament]]. After beating 4-seeded [[Tennessee Tech]] in their first game of the regional, the Tigers would lose their next game to the 3-seeded [[Oklahoma State Cowboys]]. Clemson then proceeded to win their next three games to advance out of the loser's bracket and on to the Super Regional round of the tournament. With the win, Jack Leggett extended his streak to 11-0 in home games that clinch a regional or super regional championship. In the Super Regionals, Clemson traveled to [[Tempe, Arizona]] to take on the number five national seed [[Arizona State]]. The Sun Devils defeated Clemson in the first two games of the best-of-three series, earning a trip to the [[College World Series]] in [[Omaha, Nebraska]]. The losses ended Clemson's season with a record of 44 wins and 22 losses. ===Coaching staff=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Name ! Title ! First Season at CU ! Alma Mater |- |[[Jack Leggett]] |Head Coach |1994 |[[University of Maine|Maine]] (1976) |- |Tom Riginos |Associate Head Coach |2003 |[[Stetson University|Stetson]] (1990) |- |Kyle Bunn |Assistant Head Coach |2008 |[[The Citadel, The Military College of South Carolina|The Citadel]] (2000) |- |Toby Bicknell |Volunteer Assistant Coach |2007 |[[Wingate University|Wingate]] (2002) |} ==Schedule/Results== {| class="toccolours" width=95% style="clear:both; margin:1.5em auto; text-align:center;" |- ! colspan=2 style="background:#330066" | 2008 Clemson Tigers baseball Game Log |- valign="top" |
